thread.title: Vin Lananna, Allyson Felix and the track world take another step toward the IAAF World Indoor Championships
thread.title_full: Vin Lananna, Allyson Felix and the track world take another step toward the IAAF World Indoor Championships | OregonLive.com

author: Ken Goe | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Vin Lananna, Allyson Felix and the track world take another step toward the IAAF World Indoor Championships
text:
TrackTown USA president Vin Lananna pronounced himself satisfied Tuesday with the International Association of Athletics Federations' visit at the Oregon Convention Center.
The visit provided a snapshot view of preparations for the World Indoor Track & Field Championships, March 17-20 at the convention center and the Moda Center.
Lananna and several prominent U.S. athletes spoke at a media availability.
"This is moving at a fast pace," Lananna said. "We're five months out, and there is a tremendous amount of buzz globally about this event."
Lananna is hoping for a meet that is as fan-friendly and athlete-friendly as possible.
He was encouraged by the reactions he got on Tuesday from an athletes panel that included, among others, four-time Olympic gold medalist Allyson Felix and Jason Richardson, the 2012 Olympic silver medalist in the 110-meter hurdles.
"There is this idea that the athletes only want to focus on competition and not do anything else," Lananna said. "We heard a very different message from these athletes. They want to rub shoulders with the spectators."
Indoor track is more conducive to fan-athlete interaction, Lananna said.
"It's louder, it's faster, people are closer to the track --it's all that stuff," Lananna said.
He will try to export some of that off-site.
Medal ceremonies will take place on the other side of the Willamette River, at Pioneer Courthouse Square.
Lananna wants to have an orchestra in place to play the national anthem of the winner's country live. Spectators will be able to sip a beverage in an on-site beer garden as they take it in.
Allyson Felix Talks About The 2016 World Indoor Championships Felix hopes to double in the 200 and 400 in the 2016 Olympics.
Felix and Richardson shot commercials to promote the World Indoor on Monday night.
"I had to get my inner-Denzel Washington on," Richardson quipped. "In between takes, every now and then I had to ask myself what would Meryl do?"
Richardson said he hopes to compete at the World Indoor Championships.
"The plan is to do World Indoors," he said. "But of course, the biggest goal of the year is the Olympics."
Felix said she normally uses indoor track to train for the outdoor season.
She earned 2012 Olympic gold in the 200. She won the 2015 World Championships in the 400. She would love to run both at the 2016 Olympics, and is taking a hard look at what makes sense for Portland.
She wants to compete in the World Indoor. This will be the first time since 1987 it's been held in the U.S., and only the second time ever.
"I'm very excited about this event, and that it is here," she said. "I think it's about time."
Ben Blankenship of Eugene-based Oregon Track Club Elite will have added motivation for the 2016 indoor season.
He missed making the 2015 USA Track & Field World Outdoor Championships team in the 1,500 by .02 of a second last summer at Hayward Field.
"It was a disappointment, obviously," Blankenship said. "I think I recovered fairly well."
He went on to post some strong results on the European circuit. And Blankenship's season leading up to the USATF Championships was successful, too.
He was second in the mile and two-mile at the 2015 USA Indoor Championships, and anchored Team USA's world-record-setting, distance medley relay at the World Relays.
He plans to run at this year's USATF Indoor, March 11-12, also at the Oregon Convention Center, and hopes to qualify for the World Indoor.
"I hope to build on this year and make the world indoor and outdoor teams," he said.
Blankenship has an affinity for indoor track.
"I like the environment and I like the setting," he said. "And this year, I especially like that it's 100 miles away from my house."
Lananna said about 58 percent of available World Indoor tickets have been sold.
To this point, fans only have been able to purchase ticket packages for all three days of competition in the convention center.
The men's and women's pole vault will take place in the Moda Center on March 17, and will be free.
"We're going to wait and keep going with the packages," Lananna said.
He said he expects single-session tickets to become available after Jan. 1. Tickets to the USATF Indoor Championships also will go on sale then.
